column14:
As a speech-language pathologist, do you work with children (ages 0-21) who are emergent bilinguals?



Definition of emergent bilinguals: any child who comes from a home where a language other than or in addition to English is spoken by some members of the family, regardless of proficiency level. This includes children who may not be using spoken language as well as children with language impairments or intellectual disabilities.
column15:
Do any of the emergent bilinguals you provide SLP services to use AAC?
 

Definition of an AAC user: any child who communicates using aided or unaided augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) modalities to supplement or replace their speech. AAC systems may be high tech (e.g., speech-generating devices, mobile technologies with AAC apps) or low tech (communication boards or books) and may or may not include both of the child's languages and may or may not be the child's primary communication modality.

column245: During the COVID-19 pandemic,communication is key for those with complex needs.The ability to communicate has never been more necessary than now during the COVID-19 pandemic. Just as we are finding alternative ways to stay connected with family and friends, health care providers are turning to innovations that allow them to communicate with patients who face challenges with verbal communication due to breathing difficulties, sudden intubations and/or the inability of their loved ones to be present to assist. Communication experts at our hospitals are continually adapting to patient needs and ensuring each individual has the effective tools they need to stay in contact with their care team and loved ones.This is where augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) comes in.

I started focusing less on the actual goal (production of 2+words, navigation, etc) and focused more on parent coaching. My entire goals changed. If we were judging based on the new goals I established during the pandemic (parent participation, parent programming on devices), then I could say with much confidence that they have made tremendous progress.
I also work with students who have not been included in small group cohorts, so for the most part they were at home. They were receiving 1:1 attention from parents and 1:1 intervention with me. So students made tremendous progress. 
I will note that now students are attending small group cohorts again and I am providing teletherapy sessions still. We were making much more progress in the home setting with parents collaborating. Now with classmates around, staff wearing masks, etc, it has proved to be much more difficult.
